Brief Hospital Course:
___ with PMHx notable for schizophrenia and alzheimer's dementia 
and stroke (R AICA (likely artery-to-artery embolic from 
occluded R
vertebral artery) and small vessels supratentorial infarcts
(likely due to microvascular risk factors)), who was initially 
admitted to the MICU on ___ from ___'s locked memory unit 
with one week of worsening lower extremity weakness, gait 
instability, and progressive somnolence found to have septic 
shock and possible GTC seizure for which he was intubated. He 
was treated with antibiotics for proctocolitis and pneumonia, 
extubated, and transferred to the medical floor with gradual 
improvement ___ his mental status (to recent baseline of ___ word 
responses), thought to be due likely to toxic metabolic 
encephalopathy ___ the setting of poor substrate and infection. 
Workup during this hospitalization was also concerning for 
late-latent syphillis versus neurosyphilis on the basis of 
negative RPR with positive treponemal testing and no clear 
history of syphilis treatment with treatment as described below.

MICU COURSE ___
========================  
# Encephalopathy
Developed acute encephalopathy ___ ED after a week of progressive
weakness and gradual encephalopathy along with lower extremity
weakness. Patient underwent an extensive workup while ___ the 
ICU, including an LP (attempted at bedside on night of ___ 
by ICU team and then obtained successfully by neurology consult 
service later ___ the day) with CSF showing 0 TNCs, protein of 32 
and normal glucose, Whipple PCR, BMP, EEG etc. Concern for 
seizure
activity and prolonged post-ictal state though EEG without overt
seizure activity. Infectious evaluation did not reveal a CNS
infection. Rare generalized discharges on EEG so neurology 
recommended continuing Keppra. Likely toxic metabolic given 
significant improvement ___ mental status after antibiotic 
treatment. Extubated on ___ without issue.

# Feculent vomiting
# CT Findings of colitis and proctitis. noted to have feculent 
emesis prior to presentation, intubated for airway protection, 
with OG tube placed on low-intermittent suction initially. CT 
A/P with IV contrast ___ with no show signs of SBO or other 
obstructive process. Repeat CT ___ with oral and IV contrast 
with no e/o obstruction or intrabdominal abscess but with 
evolution from proctitis to mild segmental colitis of the 
descending colon. Per report,
patient was afebrile until after intubation, and it's unclear if
he had infectious symptoms prior to presentation. Differential
would include viral or bacterial gastroenteritis (given CT
findings with proctitis) vs. gallstone ileus (given
cholelithiasis on imaging, though patient reportedly stooling ___
the ED) versus inflammatory bowel disease. Norovirus and C. diff
negative. Continued vancomycin/cefepime/flagyl for 7d course 
while ___ the ICU. Started on a clear diet after extubation on 
___.

# Undifferentiated shock and hypotension 
# Fever. Presented with hypotension and fever. 
Differential includes etiologies of distributive shock -- sepsis
(febrile) or vasoplegia (sedation, neurologic). Sources of
infection would include GI and possible CNS as above though low 
suspicion for bacterial meningitis as above. ___ have had some
component of hypovolemia given elevated lactate though
hypotension persisted after IVF reuscitation and lactate
normalization, arguing against this. Low suspicion for other
causes of shock including hemorrhagic and obstructive. S/p LP
___ as above without evidence of CNS abnormality. CT chest on 
___ showed
RUL and bilateral lower lobe aspiration and likely pneumonia. CT
abd/pelvis showed extension of protocolitis to include more of
the colon. Was initially on vanc/cefepime flagyl and transition 
to cefepime and flagyl for intended 7 day course.

# Hypervolemia
Patient was significantly positive for LOS ___ the setting of
volume resuscitation ___ the MICU. Grossly edematous on exam. 
Diuresed with IV lasix while ___ MICU.

# Central line associated thrombus
Report of RUE swelling by nursing on ___. RUE Doppler ___
showed non-occlusive thrombus surrounding right internal jugular
venous catheter with good flow on Doppler. Placed on heparin 
gtt. Will need 3 months of anticoagulation.

# Bradycardia. Noted to be bradycardic to the ___ for most of 
ICU stay without drop ___ BPs. Hemodynamically stable. Unclear 
etiology. Patient not on any
culprit medications.

# Transaminitis
Likely medication effect. Does have cholelithiasis but bili is
not elevated. RUQUS wnl, hepatitis serologies pending. Concern
for DILI. Hepatitis serologies showed immunity to HBV and HAV Ab
positivity, thought to represent previous infections.

# Lower extremity weakness
Reports of a week or so of progressive ___ weakness. LP and exam
inconsistent with GBS. Unclear etiology.
 
# Thrombocytopenia 
Does not fit timeline of HITT; no recent heparin exposure prior
to admission. 4 T score ___, low probability for HITT. Likely
marrow suppression ___ the setting of sepsis. No known liver
disease. Possibly ___ the setting of sepsis as he was noted to 
improve throughout the course of his ICU stay.

# Anemia
Hgb downtrending 12.0 --> 10.5 ___ the ED post ___ IVF (varying
reports of how much IVF given ___ ED). Hgbs have been relatively

MEDICINE FLOOR COURSE ___
====================================
ACUTE ISSUES
============
# Toxic metabolic encephalopathy
# Seizure
# Lower extremity weakness
Patient initially presented with one week of worsening mental 
status, gait instability, and decreased verbal output. He was
noted to have episodes of abnormal movements of bilateral upper 
and lower extremities, initially thought to be GTCs. Likely 
toxic metabolic encephalopathy ___ the setting of poor substrate 
and sepsis. Neurology was consulted, and on further EEG review 
it was thought that his seizure was likely metabolic ___ the 
setting of infection and his keppra was discontinued. He did 
have continued rigidity and tremors which were thought to be 
secondary to his long term antipsychotic use. However given his 
history of decompensation off of these medications, they were 
continued as he has been stabilized on this regimen thus far.

# Possible Neurosyphilis vs Latent syphillis
FTA-Abs reactive with negative RPR and VDRL of CSF negative. 
Difficult to assess for symptoms of neurosyphilis given baseline 
mental status and neurological exam. Patient was started on IV 
penicillin pending additional Treponemal Particle Agglutination 
testing, which also returned positive. ID was consulted, with 
plan to treat with a 10 day course of IV penicillin to cover for 
both neurosyphilis or late latent syphilis (D1: ___. He does 
not need additional treatment or testing once this course of IV 
PCN is completed.

# HTN
Persistently elevated SBPs during hospitalization, improved with 
increased Lisinopril to 10MG daily.

# RIJ associated thrombus:
RUE Doppler ___ revealing non-occlusive thrombus surrounding 
RIJ venous catheter with good flow on Doppler. Placed on 
apixaban with plan for at least 3 month course (to ___.
